Um, but I was always kind of like adjacent to crypto. I I was like paying attention very closely what's happening in the space. I bought my first Bitcoin in 2013, bought my first ETH at the ICO. Was like very bullish on on Ethereum. Um, and basically like as I followed the space what I realized is like blockchains are like this really really great tool for this really small subset of very important problems. Uh, which is primarily like coordination. Um, and then what I like to call like attribution of ownership. So the blockchains are fantastic at that. But there's all these other things on the web that don't necessarily fit into that box. And you know I'm I'm very ideological. Um, I believe in like the purpose of the space. And so you know I saw that there was like a lot of opportunity to kind of tackle a bigger problem of kind of the rest of the web. Right? So like financial, money, all of that happens on chain. But there's still a lot of stuff that happens off-chain that powers a lot of the applications in the space. And so we wanted to provide the same the same sort of core qualities that blockchains give to money to web applications, mobile applications, and and you know other uh, web based uh, products.

So uh, like I think like the node operator and then on top of that you get like the resiliency of it being decentralized. So we use a technique called AJ clustering which has been around for a really long time but hasn't really been applied to this space. Um, which basically guarantees like in the event of a failure of your instance, it'll automatically reboot on a different machine. Um, and then like developers can select their replication factor so if you want three nodes in your cluster, you want 10 nodes in your cluster, and then our protocol actually optimizes the geographic distribution. So you know we'll have vali we'll have you know validators. We'll have node operators that are all around the globe, and we'll be able to allocate. Okay you'll have one instance in Europe, one in East Asia, one in No North America, one in South America. There's also other benefits that come along with that like you know when you have users in those different places, the number of hops that those users have to take to reach your application shrinks dramatically. Um, whereas right now like technically speaking you could do this on AWS but you have to manage all of it yourself. So nobody does. And so then when you know US East Ohio goes down, you know because whatever there's a storm or there's a cyber attack or something happens, all of these applications are offline. Yeah. And the crazy thing is a lot of these things that are hosted are like they're critical components of our our daily lives.
